DefinitionAwareness.question: Have you heard of the term 'digital sustainability'?
DefinitionAwareness.description: We consider Digital Sustainability an umbrella term for two aspects: Sustainable Software and Sustainable by Software. Sustainable Software concerns the sustainability of digital solutions in terms of their impact on environmental, economic, technical, social, and individual dimensions, including carbon footprint (Green IT) and process resources. Sustainable by Software describes digital solutions designed to achieve positive sustainability impacts to help individuals and organizations reach sustainability goals, such as such as the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) more effectively. Have you heard of this or a similar definition of digital sustainability before?

DefinitionAwarenessByRole.question: Have you heard of the term 'digital sustainability'?
DefinitionAwarenessByRole.description: A clear majority of practitioners in RE indicate that they are not familiar with the definition, while stakeholders in all other roles (management, technical, and research) have a clear majority indicating that they are familiar with the definition

PersonIncorporatesSustainabilityByAge.question: Do you incorporate digital sustainability considerations in your role-specific tasks? (By Age Group)
PersonIncorporatesSustainabilityByAge.description: This chart shows the breakdown of respondents who incorporate digital sustainability considerations in their role-specific tasks, segmented by age group. Each age group displays the count of 'Yes' and 'No' responses in a stacked horizontal bar format.

DefinitionAwarenessByAge.question: Have you heard of the term 'digital sustainability'?
DefinitionAwarenessByAge.description: Factors related to better familiarity with the definition were respondents over 60 years old or working at a research organization.

DefinitionAwarenessByExperience.question: Have you heard of the term 'digital sustainability'?
DefinitionAwarenessByExperience.description: Less familiarity was observed with respondents with 10 or fewer years of experience, or who responded to many questions about their organization’s sustainability practices that they were not sure. Familiarity was independent of region.

SustainabilityDimensionsByOrgType.question: Which dimensions of sustainability are actively considered in your organization's software development projects?
SustainabilityDimensionsByOrgType.description: This 100% stacked bar chart visualizes which sustainability dimensions (Environmental, Social, Individual, Economic, and Technical) are considered by different types of organizations. Organizations are grouped into three categories: Large companies (large enterprises), Research institutions (universities and research institutes), and Other organizations (all remaining types). Each group displays five bars representing the five sustainability dimensions, showing the percentage of organizations that actively consider each dimension. The green section represents organizations that consider the dimension, while the pink section represents those that do not. Only respondents whose organizations incorporate sustainable practices are included in this analysis.

SustainabilityDimensionsByAge.question: Which dimensions of sustainability are actively considered in your organization's software development projects?
SustainabilityDimensionsByAge.description: This 100% stacked bar chart visualizes which sustainability dimensions (Environmental, Social, Individual, Economic, and Technical) are considered by respondents across different age groups. The chart groups respondents into four age categories: 18-28, 29-44, 45-60, and Above 60. Each age group displays five bars representing the five sustainability dimensions, showing the percentage of respondents in that age group whose organizations actively consider each dimension. The green section represents organizations that consider the dimension, while the pink section represents those that do not. Only respondents whose organizations incorporate sustainable practices are included in this analysis.

SustainabilityDimensionsByExperience.question: Which dimensions of sustainability are actively considered in your organization's software development projects?
SustainabilityDimensionsByExperience.description: This 100% stacked bar chart visualizes which sustainability dimensions (Environmental, Social, Individual, Economic, and Technical) are considered by respondents across different professional experience levels. The chart groups respondents into three experience categories: 0-10 years, 11-20 years, and More than 20 years. Each experience group displays five bars representing the five sustainability dimensions, showing the percentage of respondents in that experience level whose organizations actively consider each dimension. The green section represents organizations that consider the dimension, while the pink section represents those that do not. Only respondents whose organizations incorporate sustainable practices are included in this analysis.

OrganizationalPracticesByOrgType.question: Organizational Practices by Organization Type
OrganizationalPracticesByOrgType.description: This 100% stacked bar chart visualizes responses to five key organizational questions across different organization types. Organizations are grouped into three categories: Other organizations, Large company, and Research. Each group displays five bars representing: (1) Has specific digital sustainability goals or benchmarks, (2) Has a dedicated sustainability or CSR team/department, (3) Incorporates sustainable development practices, (4) Reports on sustainability practices, and (5) Offers training or resources on sustainable software development. The bars show the percentage breakdown of responses: Yes (green), No (pink), and Not sure (grey). This chart helps identify how organizational sustainability practices vary across different types of organizations.

PersonIncorporatesSustainabilityByExperi.question: Do you incorporate digital sustainability considerations in your role-specific tasks? (By Professional Experience)
PersonIncorporatesSustainabilityByExperi.description: This chart shows the breakdown of respondents who incorporate digital sustainability considerations in their role-specific tasks, segmented by professional experience. Each experience group displays the count of 'Yes' and 'No' responses in a grouped vertical bar format.

PersonIncorporatesSustainabilityByMeasur.question: Do you incorporate digital sustainability considerations in your role-specific tasks? (By Organizational Context)
PersonIncorporatesSustainabilityByMeasur.description: This chart illustrates the relationship between the organizational context and whether employees incorporate sustainability into their work. Respondents are categorized by their organization's stance: 'No sustainability' (organization does not incorporate practices), 'Unclear communication' (respondent is unsure), or by the number of specific measures in place (1 to 4+). Generally, as organizations adopt more measures (goals, teams, practices, coordination, reporting, training), employees are more likely to incorporate sustainability. An exception is observed at three measures, where a specific combination often lacks training/resources, highlighting the importance of employee support.

DriversToIncorporateSustainabilityByOrgT.question: What drives you to incorporate digital sustainability in your role-related tasks?
DriversToIncorporateSustainabilityByOrgT.description: This grouped bar chart shows the percentage of respondents motivated by different drivers (Organizational policies, Personal beliefs, Client requirements, User requirements, Legal requirements), broken down by organization type (Large company, Research, Other organizations). The data highlights how drivers vary across sectors, specifically confirming that client and user requirements play a negligible role in research settings compared to industry.
